title: Logical Operators
learning_objectives: Understand the Logical Operators concept in SQL

definition.concept_explanation: Logical Operators is an important SQL concept for working with databases.

examples.title: SQL Example 1
examples.sql: create a relation with the following attributes: the key attributes of Employees (88n), the key attributes of Sponsors (d'id, p'id), and the descriptive attributes of Monitors ('/.tnt:'il). This translation is essentially the standard mapping for a relationship set, as described in Section 3.5.2. The Relational A!odd 85 ~ There is a special case in which this translation can be refined by dropping the Sponsors relation. Consicler the Sponsors relation. It has attributes pid, did, and since;

examples.title: SQL Example 2
examples.sql: insert a GoodStudents row by inserting a row into Students, using null values in columns of Students that do not appear in GoodStudents (e.g., sname, login). Note that primary key columns are not allowed to contain null values. Therefore, if we attempt to insert rows through a view that does not contain the primary key of the underlying table, the insertions will be rejected. For example, if GoodStudents contained snarne but not ,c;

common_mistakes.title: Syntax error
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: Typo in SQL keyword. The correct keyword is FROM, not FORM.

common_mistakes.title: Missing semicolon
common_mistakes.error_message: Some databases require semicolons to end statements
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: While some SQL implementations are lenient, it's best practice to end statements with semicolons.
common_mistakes.key_takeaway: Always end SQL statements with a semicolon

practice_challenge.description: Practice using logical-operators with the practice schemas.
practice_challenge.hint: Review the examples above and try writing your own query.
practice_challenge.explanation: This is a basic query to get you started. See the linked practice problems for more challenges.
